¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	 End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	 Third Book of the Surgeon's Book of Albucasis.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	 Discourse on the restoration, dislocation, and treatment of twisting and similar conditions.
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	 This chapter is also often necessary in the art of medicine and is the restoration of a fracture or dislocation of bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	 Know that foolish physicians and the common people boast about this chapter, and those who have never examined an ancient book or read a letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	 And for this reason, because this method has been deprived among the learned in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 I myself have never been familiar with this method in any way, nor have I gained knowledge of it except through the length of reading ancient books and my devotion to understanding them until I extracted that knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I clung to experience and prolonged life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	I have already described to you all that my knowledge contains within this Chapter: and beyond what my experience has reached, after I abbreviated it for you, and released it from the prolongation of occupation, and abbreviated it at the end of abbreviation, and showed it at the end of declination; and I formed in it many shapes of instruments used within it, since it is through addition of declination, as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 I have described for you the sums and collections of fractures of bones, from those whose premise is necessary before we begin the recollection of fractured limbs, and various ones, if any one of them.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary that we state in the preface of this Chapter, the main points and headings, to which the understanding of the craftsman is first required regarding their truth; namely that you, and those who are quick, should know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 Therefore, I say that when any fracture, dislocation, twisting, or accident happens, then it is necessary to rush at once to bleed him and solve the problem, or both at the same time; unless something forbids it, such as weakness of strength; or he who has it is a child, an old man weakened, or there is a time of intense heat, or very intense cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then let him be content with his food, cold vegetables, and turnips, and beans; and let wine, heavy meats, and filling foods from every kind of food that fills the veins with blood be prohibited.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until you are secure from hot fever and not fearful of the emission of matter to the limb; then let the sick person return first to his own diet with which his custom is accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When the broken bone begins to heal, it is then necessary that the sick person be fed with nourishing foods in abundance, thick, heavy, containing viscosity; such as food made from cooked wheat with water, rice, and heads, and feet, and entrails of cattle, and eggs, and fresh fish; and thick wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 When this regimen is applied, the healing of the fracture occurs more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And know that broken bones, in men who are in the first old age and are weakened, cannot always be united and consolidated according to their nature, due to drying out of their members; and they consolidate and unite what is from them at the end of softness, such as the bones of small children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 Nevertheless, nature annexes something resembling glue to the broken bone from all sides, in which there is thickness, with which it adheres and tightens it until they are consolidated against each other and bound together until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until it does not prohibit anything from its operations; and for this reason it is necessary that you place nourishment for the sick with heavy foods, containing viscosity and thickness, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	 And know that the types of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of the members; because a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the bone of the head: and a fracture of the bone of the chest is different from a fracture of the bone of the back: and similarly all other members are different from each other; and I come with a reminder of every type of fracture exposed in its own chapter.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 The species of bone fracture are diversified even within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 Since the fracture of it is curved, what happen in it are also stars (or studs).
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes the fracture of it happens along the length of the bone; and there are fractures called stars (or studs), that is, studs, and additions coming forth, as in a reed when a knife is prepared for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And not proceeding; and it is a fracture with wound and rupture at the head; and it is a small cleft fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And each species has its skill, or proper tool for its restoration, according to which its memory will come, distinguished in their places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from that which the bone fracture is known, there is its curvature, and its prominence; and its appearance to the sense, and its sound when you press it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When therefore the curvature is not appearing in place, nor a sound when you touch it with pressure on the bone, nor does it find a large pain; then there is no fracture there, indeed it is possible that it is a curvature or a small cleft fracture; therefore, do not move it with your hand and compression at all, but rather put some medicine over it where its memory is, after the appropriate time has passed; then compress the bandage with subtle tension.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 And know that when the place is curved and split into two, except for studs (or stars), remove all parts from their natural position; then it will be necessary for you to begin at your hour for its correction, equalizing it before a hot abscess occurs.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 If, however, a hot abscess occurs, then let it be for several days until the abscess subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then, cut it evenly according to whatever method can be done with kindness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that the restoration of it, and its alignment, is easier than bone, in which complications may occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then tie it, as your memory recalls it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If there are complications in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this fractured limb from both parts, whether it be a hand or foot; or with your hand, if the member is small; or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 Let the position in which you place the limb be on an equal plane, according to its natural shape, until the parts of the fractured member are extended; then try to bring back those additions with all your skill, and according to whatever method you can do it in their places: and take care not to cause pain or injury due to your operation; and try, according to your strength, to apply one bone to its companion, according to the best forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 It is necessary in that hour for you to test and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If therefore you see something different there, correct it, and align it by the quantity of your skill.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And beware of excessive stretching and strong compression, as many foolish people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 For many times they cause abscesses or contractions to occur in the member through their operation; as we have already seen it happen many times through their operations.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then join after the alignment and proper operation, and binding and rest of this member, and peace and calmness; and warn the weak person about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 And make him be careful not to move it in the hour of his waking, and sleep, and turning, and restlessness, and all his movements, with all his strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 And so that it may be avoided, let there not be a position of a member with which follows pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 When he feels pain or injury while in the position of a member: then it is necessary to move him to another position from which he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 And so let that be avoided, that his position is uneven or twisted: lest there occur a twist in the member when he is to be restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 The quality of the binding for a broken member is as I have described.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 Know that broken members are differentiated by their size, and the extent of their breakage, and their shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 Those which are small, such as the arm, and finger, and shin-bone, and similar to these, then it is necessary that there be a rolling of soft, fine cloth over them.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 But those which are large, such as the hip and thigh, it is necessary that there be a broad, hard rolling over them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 Because a wide band joins a large member and binds it all around with an equally tight binding so that no stain penetrates it.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 Then after your evacuation, place an appropriate linen on it, in soft woolen over the place of the break itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 Then begin to wrap the bandage over the place of the break itself three or four times, according to what the member deserves; and tighten your hand slightly with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 Then go to the upper part away from the place of the break and bind it less than your previous binding that you applied to the broken place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then withdraw with the bandage from the place of the break slightly and soften the binding gradually until you have taken a large amount from a healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then take another dressing and wrap it again over the broken place with bandages.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 After moving with the incline towards the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 And your operation shall be in the stricture of the incline and its softening, according to what we said in the first higher incline.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then place between the inclines from soft wool or cloth that matches the twisting of the fracture, if there is twisting in it; and if not, do not place anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then incline over the same wound another.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Afterwards, place evenly on these inclines stars properly made immediately, if there is no swelling or hot abscess.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 If there is swelling or abscess in it; then place over it what sits on that abscess, and remove the swelling; and let it remain for some days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then bind over them the stars.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 The stars shall be from the middle parts of wide reeds, shaved and skillfully formed; or they shall be made of wood from which cribra are made, which are made from pine, yew, palm branches or calingi; and let the width of all the stars be according to this form and this same shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 However, it is necessary that the star placed over the tendon should be slightly larger and wider than the others; and the length of the star shall be according to what allows the limb in terms of size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then bind over the stars with another bandage, according to the first stricture.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then bind over it with threads properly, according to what we said about the stricture; and your stricture shall be above the fracture more; and the greater the distance from the fracture, the less the stricture.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 It is necessary that the threads be of medium thickness and fineness, and be made of soft flax.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 If threads are thick, as I saw in the operation of fools tying threads twisted from flax cords, it is a great error: because a constriction falls out with them beyond quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 Fine threads do not agree again: because you will not achieve what you want through the constriction with them.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 And it is not proper that there be less than a finger's breadth between the anvil and the hammer.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If the weak [person] is injured by the extremities of the anvils after the constriction in healthy places: then place under them soft wool or carded wool until nothing is injured from that.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 But when there is a fracture with a wound and there occurs disruption in the skin, I will come with its discussion in chapter two under special cases.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every broken limb should be tied with anvils from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 What is meant by this, is that when a limb is large, you should not place superior anvils on it unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your safety from the risk of cold abscesses.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 This is the method of plasters which the ancients used to restore, which are placed on a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	¶ Common Plaster Method abbreviated, restoring a fracture, suitable for many constitutions, particularly women and children: because it is from that which heat does not conquer nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And it is to receive from the flour mill dust and it is the marrow of the wheat which hangs on the walls of the mill near the movement of the stones: and make this as it is, except that you sift it with egg white: and place its composition not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	¶ Another Plaster Method, restoring a fracture, dislocation and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Prepare almess, laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugath. Grind all of them until they are as fine as ten parts of myrrh, five parts of aloes, and twenty parts of alethil. Sieve them and mix with alethil water, or with sheep's white grease if the disease is hot.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is of good composition, restores broken bones quickly, and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method for the plaster which also treats fractures and dislocations.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Prepare mugath, mess, white alteae, all of them pounded until as fine as ten parts of myrrh, five parts of aloes, six parts of acacia, twenty parts of Armenian pounded boli, and sieve them. Mix with water or sheep's white grease and administer.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another method for the plaster for joining bones and separating them from their places: it relieves pain and swelling in those places, and heals broken bones and fractures.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Take boiled wool, immerse it in vinegar and hot oil, then place it over the affected area.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 In this plaster there is no healing power, but it is good for the relief of hot abscesses and it effectively drives out pains.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Another method for the plaster that restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take the leaves of the fig tree and the wild papaver: grind them all and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Another short method for the plaster administered in the healing of a broken bone, and when you wish to resolve the remaining abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Prepare the root of alteae, chamomile, flowers of violets, and herb flour, all one part: grind them all and mix with wine if the limb is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is heated (the wound), then make that with water of coriander (juice) or with water and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another stronger method for healing, stronger than the first, when a hard abscess occurs during restoration of a limb.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Take equal parts of althea root, linseed, balaustia, lentil, samsuc, viole flowers, and chamomile. Grind all together and make a paste with water of willow, sweet water, or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply the above to the member according to its heat and calmness of the heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 Hippocrates himself did not say in his book that it should be placed on a fractured member during its healing, except for plaster made from tallow and oil, not anything else; and he said that it should have a middle state between thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galenus, however, saw fit that they should be placed on a fractured member during its healing, things that have the dryness of heat, such as myrrh and aloes and olibanum and similar ones mentioned earlier.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 Method of plaster for injury and pain relief.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Take equal parts of mugath (althea), chickpeas, human hairs (or bird feathers), althea root, and salt. Grind and sieve and make a paste from it; and make plaster out of it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The amount by which the ligature should remain, then dissolve, is such that you consider whether pain does not occur, nor itching, nor is the bone moved from its place; then do not dissolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If itching or discomfort or swelling occurs in the place; then hurry and dissolve it within an hour and remove the plaster from it; and take a soft cloth or a soft sea sponge moistened; and submerge it in warm water and wash the place with it until the itching subsides and the pain is soothed.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then let the member rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place a scalded wool upon it, immerse it in vinegar and oil (or rose oil), or oil: and bind it on top of it at night until you are secure from the hot abscess, and let the swelling of the member subside, and remove its pain.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat it for a delicate bandage and a small plaster: and do not bind it tightly with your first constraint, and delicately with it until it heals.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling and all other symptoms are already completely removed, and if you need plaster and bandage, then repeat it as you did at first equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If nothing of what we said happens in the member, then do not loosen it, unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when it is released after twenty days, according to what appears to you from the loosening of the member, as we said, until when a fracture adheres and coagulation of the flesh approaches on it: add also in the bandage more than your first binding: and add also in the thickening of food for the sick, according to what was previously remembered.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 If you see a place of the fracture already to dry out and thin more than is necessary: then know that nutrition is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Therefore, anoint the member with warm water at every corner where you loosen it, and let it be for all three days, and rub the bandage slightly.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 By this operation, nourishment flows to the member, and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 But what the foolish restorers do from a fracture of the member instead of first restoring it as is necessary, and they restore it according to crookedness, this is an error in their operation, and there is great fear: and if it were right, they would have said that in their old books, and operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I have nowhere seen their trace in that entirely, and it is more correct that it should not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 On the making of a fracture in the head.
Caput III.	 Chapter 3.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 Types of fractures are diverse, and their forms many; and their causes are distinguished.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For there is a fracture which occurs from striking with a sword; and the blow removes bone completely as far as it penetrates into the siphac, which is beneath the bone, just as an ax does in wood; and for this reason this type of fracture is called Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 Or the sword cuts something of a bone and cuts its face, but does not penetrate with the cut to its end; and this type of fracture is called Kalan, that is, Absolute Lever.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And there is a wound of two types of fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And from a fracture there is one that is a crushing or grinding; and its cause is a blow with a stone, or falling on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this fracture is also penetrating, which approaches the membrane, which is beneath the bone; or it is on the face of a bone; and this type of fracture has two forms, either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And from a fracture there is one that is hidden in the bone in its finest part; and it is a small crack, and for this reason this type of fracture is called Capillar.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And among them there is a fracture that occurs from falling or striking with a stone, and similar things; which make the layer of the bone enter within, and it forms a hollow in its place; just as happens to the caldrons of brass when they are struck, and part of them enters within.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 And this indeed often occurs in the bones of moist heads, such as those of children's heads.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 And all these types of fractures of the sternum are separate, and I shall come with the recollection of that entire thing in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 And we know all these types of fractures by detection over it and examination of them with tests, and removal of the corrupted flesh that is over them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 The Capillary type is known by this: it is detected over the bone, scraped off and then bound over it with pitch; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In the treatment of a fracture, consider first the condition of the patient: then, if you see signs in his condition that indicate fear, such as cholera vomiting, extension, loss of intelligence, loss of voice, fainting, acute fever, eye discharge, redness of eyes, and similar signs in many other conditions, it is most likely not to heal; and if you see signs that do not frighten you and you hope for recovery: then begin the treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If someone comes to you wounded first with the wound, and it is in winter days, then it is necessary that you strive for the removal of the bone before the fourteenth day according to all circumstances.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 And if it is in summer days, then it is necessary that you hurry to remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is under the bone from fat corrupts and the signs that we have mentioned occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the fracture of the bone has already reached the fat touching the brain, and is with grating and pulling: then it is necessary that you cut the broken and ground part, as I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 And it is necessary that you shave the head of the wounded person: and scrape over the bone in any way possible for you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light for the patient.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If it happens to you during bone examination, a blood flow or a hot abscess: then oppose him with what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 And it is to be filled with linen soaked in wine and rose oil, and let the wound rest until the abscess settles down, and be careful of bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin in the cure of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 One method is to cut the bone with a curved blade: and this is its shape.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 Then administer another scalpel, broader but shorter than the first: and this is its shape.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then also administer another scalpel wider than the second.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 And the second method is to have a number of scalpels of different sizes, some wider than others and some shorter; they should be at the end of their sharpness, and made of iron or bronze; use them with ease when striking the scalpel so as not to strike the head and injure it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If the bone is hard: then it is necessary to bore around it before you administer the scalpel, with the chisels that are called terebras, which do not penetrate deeply; they are not called so because they do not pass beyond the limit of the bone to what is behind it; because the terebra has a rounded end above that which is underneath the head and is sharp like an edge, and a small circle prevents it from sinking and penetrating the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 It is also suitable for you to take a large number of these chisels, one of which corresponds to the thickness of the bone, until there are as many terebras as the skull requires; the sharpness of each should be according to the thickness of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the form of three species of trephines, or trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality of perforating around a broken bone is as follows: you should place the trepan on the bone and turn it with your fingers until you know that it has already penetrated the bone.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the trepan to another place, and place there that which is between every hole of such size as a finger's breadth or approximately so.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with the saw what is between every hole in the bone, and make it finer than possible at the end of the thinness, as we have said, until you have chiseled the bone, either with your hand or with some other tools which you have prepared for that purpose, such as tenaliae and fine forpices.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And it is necessary that you take every care to ensure that the trepan or saw does not touch anything from the skin.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you therefore perforate the bone by circumscribing it and it has been separated from the skin, if it is continuous with it, and you extract it, it is necessary that you grind and level off the extremity which remains in the bone with another similar saw.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 However, it should be thin and delicate compared to other saws.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If something remains of the small bones and splinters, then take them with ease, with that which is at hand from your tools.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then care for the wound afterwards with linen and ointments as we have said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 And another method of operation is easy, entirely far from fear; which Galen said and praised greatly; and this is his saying.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 It is necessary for you first to begin by exposing the bone from the place where the fracture is more intense and clearer; until when you have exposed that part and placed under it the extremity of this saw with a concave shape, which has this form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 The rounded part (of the eye) cuts nothing gently: and the sharp part of it proceeding in both its sides as you see, so that the rounded part of the lens is attached to the sclera, with its sharp edge incident on the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike upon the Incisor with a small hammer until you cut through the bone easily, as it is usually turned (in operation): and be careful that no cloth slips into what is being cut, which you fear might happen altogether.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 If the physician were not more foolish than men, nor more ignorant of his craft, nor asleep, then if something remained attached to the bone from the cloth in certain places, he would cut it away with the sharp edge of the incisor's lenticular part and free it easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is freed from it without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If the bone is not broken through to the cloth, and what is being cut away from the bone is its face, with roughness and subtle irregularities remaining in it: then it is necessary that you smooth out that roughness and remove those irregularities with fine rasps which you have prepared in various quantities, so that it is possible for you to administer more suitable and correct ones according to the procedure of the operation, and the broken bone and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 And it is necessary that you administer according to your judgment, first smoothing the bone more broadly with those rasps.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer one after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 And do not cease to do this in continuity until you come to administer more thinly and finer of them all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In each of the remaining small cracks and a fine break, care must be taken according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And it is a matter that cannot be hidden upon all, to which in this art there is any study, and it stood upon what we have written, and we showed in large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If however a piece of cloth is found to be retained when you excise bone: then it is necessary that you take linen cloth according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it on the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another piece of cloth, either doubled or tripled, and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it on top of the first one; and do that as easily as possible above it, so that it is not heavy.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer on top of it a wide bandage; and do not tighten it except according to the size that holds the wound only; and release it with this care for one day or two days until you are assured from hot inflammation.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it (the bandage), and administer afterwards medications with which excessive dryness is superfluous; such as the roots of garlic, and flour of herbs, and powder of incense, and aristolochia, and similar ones: and it is that you make from these medications a powder, which is to be sprinkled on the wound like dry ones.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And universally administer on it all medicine with the property of purifying and not biting.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 And be careful according to your ability that the wound is clean during your treatment; neither let there be filth from ointments, nor dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 Neither let the pus gather in it entirely; because when pus gathers on a cerebral cloth, it corrupts it and rots itself, and great evil follows after that for the patient: and already it has happened in the head, when the bone is cleaned from it, especially when care is neglected for it, blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Consider then, if afflictions occur to the sick as we have said, know that it is undoubtedly dangerous.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 If there is no discoloration (nigredo) unless it arises from the medication placed upon it and it is in the virtue of that medicine to cause discoloration: then you should take a portion from honey, three portions from rose oil, and anoint with them a cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then place it on a sheep's bladder (siphac): afterwards treat it with the remedies suitable for healing until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 [Section heading: Restoration of the nose when broken.]
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that the nose is not broken except by the two upper parts of it together or one of them: because they consist of two bones; since its lower part (inferius) is cartilaginous, it does not break and does not happen unless there is rubbing, distortion, and deviation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of the two parts is broken, then it is necessary that you insert a small finger into the nose's opening and hold the fracture with your index and thumb from the outside until the nose returns to its natural shape; this should be done skillfully and easily.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And beware that your treatment does not cause pain to the sick person.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and the finger does not reach it: then you should apply pressure to the end of the radius where there is a slight swelling.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If the fracture is in two parts, then make a similar one and approach with its healing on the first day of the fracture if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day in the presence of warm cauterizers (apostematis).
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a strip of linen from a linen cloth into the end of the nose if the fracture is in one part; or insert two strips of linen if the fracture is in two parts: and let there be a swelling of sufficient size in the linen to fill the opening of the nose.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And certain restorers of old times said, that linen should be soaked in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 That rather does not seem to me, but it is necessary that linen be soaked in cow's milk, prepared with miller's flour.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then let the linen be removed when the bone hardens and the cartilage hardens.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the place of linen in the nose, after a soft cloth has been laid upon it; and this is done so that the linen holds the fracture of the nose more strongly, and so that the weak are not hindered from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you wish, do it; and if you wish, do linen.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 And if it happens that the nose again when treating an abscess while operating, pack the nose with hot plasters, or with cerotic, or with pitch softened in rose oil, or a little bit of aloes.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 But if an abscess does not occur, then it is necessary that the pack be made with sesame flour and incense powder prepared with cow's milk.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft wool on top of it, and do not tie the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If the bones of the nose are broken by a small fracture or crushed, then it is necessary that you cut above them and extract them with instruments suitable for them.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then be cauterized and care for it with that which adheres to it, and let it heal with suitable packs or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If there is a wound between the nose and lip, then it is necessary to care for it with linen; and administer a lead tube until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of the lower jaw when it breaks.
Caput V.	 Head V. (Fifth Chapter)
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is disrupted and its fracture is not accompanied by a wound: then examine whether its fracture is only on the outside and it does not break into two, and it bends towards the inside: then its recognition is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 Therefore, if the fracture is in the right part of it (the jaw), insert your left index finger into the weak bone: similarly, if the fracture is in the left lower jaw, then insert your right index finger: and push with it the bulge of the fracture towards the outside with ease from within the bone using your other hand properly from the inside part of the bone, and with it equalize it.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the fracture of the lower jaw is already separated into two, then it is necessary to administer extension from both parts, according to rectitude: until it is possible to equalize it.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 If however, disturbance or disruption has already occurred among the teeth, then bind those which you hope will remain with a thread of gold, silver, silk, or floss.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place upon the broken lower jaw pieces of lead.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place over it a double cloth and put over the cloth a large star-shaped plaster well made: or an equal piece of shoe sole leather in length of the lower jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind it above (the dressing), according to the preparation of its binding and the fitting of its application, until it is not destroyed: and order the patient to rest quietly: and put his softened food.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If you think that something has changed its shape by some means: then hurry and undo it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then straighten what has been changed from it, and plaster it with flour mill powder, with egg white or wheat flour, after you have removed the lead: and place over the plaster soft wool.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While that adhesive plaster remains on it and the bone arrangement does not change, leave it undisturbed until it heals; or tie up the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 This fracture is often tied for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If a warm abscess occurs meanwhile, then administer what I said earlier for its relief until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if there is a fracture with a wound, consider.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 If the bone fragment is already separating from the bone or the flesh, then be careful with this. Use fine instruments to remove the bone fragments that are suitable for you in removing them from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If the wound opening is narrowed, then expand it with a leech according to your needs.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you remove the flesh, and nothing remains of it, or if the wound opening is large: and if not, cover it with plasters that are suitable for this, and let it heal until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 [Title] On the restoration of a fork when it breaks.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 Much indeed is broken by the Furcula from the anterior part, near the humerus, and its fracture is made according to one of the three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 Either it is broken and separated into two, apart from which complications may occur within it; and it is easier for its restoration.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 Or, so that complications occur in the bone itself; and it is difficult for its restoration.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 Or, so that it is a fracture with wounding.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 And the procedure for it when the fracture is without wounding is as follows: make two attendants present, so that one of them holds the assisting hand that follows the broken Furcula, and the other stretches the neck towards the side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then you must equalize the fracture with your fingers until it takes on its form, as is required; there should be no prominence nor hollow within it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If you require more stretching, then it is necessary that you place a small ball made of cloth or wool beneath the weakened patient's neck, and its size should correspond to your need; and stretch, lift, and apply the ball with your hand until you equalize the fracture, as is required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you cannot draw out the extremity of the Furcula to the outside because it has reached deep within; then it is necessary that the weakened patient lies on his neck and places a splint of medium size under his shoulder; and press an assistant on his humerus towards the lower part, so that the bone of the Furcula in the deep part is lifted upwards; at that time, correct the fracture and equalize it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 If you feel a splinter from the Furcula and it moves; then it is necessary that you probe over it and draw out the splinter easily.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If it is retained in the bone, then prepare a probe for its incision with one of the Incisorium you have prepared for that purpose; after placing an instrument under the Furcula to protect the Sifach (ligament), and this instrument can be made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 It resembles a snail without a hollow part.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 Let its width be according to that which you require for it depending on the size of the bone and its smallness.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 The length (of it) should also be, as much as possible, for your operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 It shall have two ends, as you see: one wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If however the wound split which you cut when you pulled out the splinter of bone, is wide, and you are free from heat: then gather together two lips of the wound with suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 And if the split is small, or you fear a hot abscess: then fill the wound with cloths, and lint according to the size of the wound cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If a hot abscess occurs, then pour oil of rose into it, and vinegar, and wine, and place (something) on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 The narrowing (of a bone) without wound and without cutting, is to place on the bone a plaster made from flour milled with egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And place a soft cushion over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a sphere under the sensitive part of it, if needed.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take a roll (tourniquet), that which the Saracens hold, which is very long: and its width should be as large as one palm or approximately that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place lint (together) on top of the cushion and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take a needle from a delicate wood, whose width is three fingers, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then insert it into the cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then insert the cloth with the needle at the place of the bleeding that falls upon the fracture and place.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place the astringent (tourniquet) upon the fracture as it is turned, and insert it upon its healthy part and its weak part: and tie it over all parts, so that the narrowing holds the fracture properly: and this is what must not be concealed from you, and all of it, so that the needle does not move from the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 It is necessary that you examine the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 Whenever the ligament becomes soft and you see the splinter being removed, then adjust it and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the sick person's sleep on his back and put a small pebble under his pulse during his sleep so that when he is awakened, help will be near him from the side of himself.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 The break in the collarbone is to be treated by elevating the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Or bind the arm to the neck; and do not loosen the binding, unless it happens in the place of occurrence from itching or from an abscess, for twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see his face turning towards it.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add a small amount to the constriction, and let it go until it heals and hardens.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 The break in the collarbone is tightened and supported most for twenty days; and sometimes it happens in fewer than that number of days in some people.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the healing of a broken oar.
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 Rarely does an oar break at its wide part; and it is not broken except from the edges of it.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When it breaks at its wide part and breaks in the middle, and this is not known except by touch; then prepare for it according to the shape of the break.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 Reduce it to its natural form by any means that is possible for you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then put on the place flour of milling with egg white and soft wool, and put a small cloth on top.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place over it a splint made of thin wood according to the size of the oar, or slightly larger but not much so.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If there is a hollow under the star (mark) on any spatula's handle, then fill that hollow with soft wax until the mark sinks down evenly.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then coat it on top with long alum paste, with appropriate constriction and strength of the star, until it is not removed from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 And consider the ligature (bandage) each day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever the ligature softens, coat it and if the star moves from its place, let it lie weak on its healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 The spatula is restored within twenty or thirty days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When this number (20 or 30) is complete, then loosen the ligature: and you will be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it (the spatula handle) is made of bones whose fracture is not feared, nor their solution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If a splinter comes out of the bone and pierces under the skin, then cut above it and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do as we have said in the treatment of a dislocated collarbone with warm poultice, if something happens from it (the spatula handle).
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Chapter on the restoration of a broken breastbone.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 The breastbone sometimes breaks in half and this rarely happens.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 Its extremities break more often and are crushed due to accidents of it.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	 When its middle breaks and declines towards the lower part, and it causes a violent pain, difficulty in breathing, coughing, and possibly vomiting blood, and a hollow is declared on the broken bone and not concealed from the sense, the restoration of it is that it lies weak on its back: and place between the spatulas its pulvinar.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	 Then press the arms and bring the ribs from both sides or flanks with hands: and grind it evenly in accordance with any way that can be possible for it to return to the shape of the bone, as is necessary.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	 Then place upon it an ointment and a stopper, and on top of it an astel from subtle wood (such as willow or alder), or chalking (a type of plaster) and similar ones, after you have rolled it up in a cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	 Then bind it firmly to the broken bone so that it is not moved: and go with the bandage according to its round shape towards the back several times, and tighten it appropriately using a suitable ligature.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.
