Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	 Then, with your bent hand, press the dislocated joint, because it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	 Then place an ointment on it, and pack it with cotton, and bind it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	 However, the extremities that follow the elbow, which are continuous with it, do not become dislocated unless rarely.
Quod si dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it becomes dislocated on any day: then it must be reduced and set according to what has been said, and what you have prepared for yourself.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	 Then place upon it [the wound] the plaster, and the leeches, and the ligature.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	 And instruct the sick man to adhere to tranquility and rest until he is healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	 When this same cure brings the edge of the arm back to its place, it should also be separated from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	 Chapter on the reduction of dislocation of the arm.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	 Know that the humerus is not dislocated, unless in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	 One of them is, it dislocates to the part of the pectoral at the lower side.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	 The second is, it dislocates to the chest part.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	 And perhaps it dislocates to the upper part of the humerus: and that happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	 Nor is it dislocated at the backside, because of the spade [splint].
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	 Nor is it dislocated to the front side, because of the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	 Indeed, it is most often dislocated and comes out to the lower side turned towards the pectoral: especially in those whose flesh is scanty.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	 Because it goes out quickly in them and enters quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	 But in those whose flesh is abundant, the reverse holds true: namely, because it goes out with difficulty and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	 And perhaps some people experience a blow or an accident and the humerus is dislocated by a hot application, and it is thought to be so because it has already been dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	 Therefore, one must experiment with that until you are certain of its nature, and then proceed in treating it.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	 And the dislocation is known when it is to the lower side turned towards the pectoral, and you shall distinguish between a dislocated humerus and a healthy humerus.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	 For you will find among them an evident difference, and in the head of the humerus there is a hollow, and beneath the pectoral at the touch of the head of the humerus as if it were an egg: and an invalid cannot bring his hand to his ear nor move it with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	 And similarly, if it is dislocated towards the chest or upward: then you will find an evident touch, and it cannot be hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	 And this kind of dislocation has an easy reduction when it is recent or the child is weak.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	 The reduction is that he elevates his hand to above.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	 Then place your thumbs beneath his, and with strength lift the joint until it is in its place; then he will elevate his hand, and stretch it upward.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	 Then put it down, for he quickly returns.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	 If it does not return as mentioned, and from the beginning when dislocation occurs are many days: then it is necessary that the sick one bathe in warm water, and receive embrocation which softens and soothes, just as if they decoct root of althea, and fenugreek, and melilotus in water, and give it.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	 Then the sick one lies on his back upon his back; and let a sphere and wool be placed under his thumb which is equal in softness and tightness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	 Then the doctor places his heel upon the sphere, and lifts the head of the humerus with force, and draws the hand of the sick one to below.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	 And another person holds the head of the sick one, so that it is not moved downward; for he quickly returns immediately.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	 And if you wish, reduce him according to this method; and it is that you make the man present who is taller than the sick one, and stands on his side, and introduces his humerus under the thumb of the sick one: and lifts the thumb of the sick one to above, until the sick one is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	 And another person pulls the hand of the sick one to below his stomach.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	 If the sick one is light: then it is necessary that he be suspended with something else, in order to weigh him down; for the dislocation quickly returns.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	 And it is also reduced according to another method; and it is that a long wooden rod is fashioned on the ground, whose head is rounded in form: like a mitten of a hammer-maker; which is neither too heavy nor too thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	 Then place it under the patient when logs of soft cloth are placed on his head, and let the patient stand according to the length of the logs.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	 Then extend his hands towards the lower part from the other side, and extend his body from the other side with force, for the joint will return to its place quickly.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	 If the reduction (restoration) is difficult by all that has been said, then use this care: and it is to take a log whose length is the size of two forearms and its width four fingers, and its thickness two fingers, with rounded head to widen its entrance into the depth for pressing, according to this shape.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	 Then wrap around his head with soft cloth logs, so as not to injure the log supporting the patient.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	 Then place it under the support of the patient, so that his hand or arm may be extended over the log to below, and tie the log above the arm and hand and lower limb.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	 Then place the arm on a step of the ladder widthwise, and extend the hand to below, and let the rest of the body hang suspended from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	 For the joint enters immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	 Since the entrance is filled to the greatest extent possible, then it is necessary that you place under the support a sphere made of wool equal in size to it.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	 Then place a prepared plaster made from milled flour with balm and egg white on the entire shoulder as it is rolled on top of it.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	 Then tie a suitable suture below the support and roll the bandage over the plaster above it, connect the patient's hand to his neck and do not move his hand for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	 It is necessary that a scanty food be placed (for the patient) until the limb recovers its strength, since it heals more quickly in this way.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	 Then it should be placed larger after seven days, or five, and it should be opened with motion.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	 If therefore it is firm and does not become soft, then it is healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	 If however the union is dislocated many times on account of the moisture that occurs to it or on account of some other cause: then it is necessary that a cautery be administered in it with three holes, according to what has been said in the chapter on cautery.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	 If this is done entirely, and the ligament is loosened after seven days, and the union does not become firm, and a plaster and pressure are applied to it several times, and it does not become firm and falls, and cannot be raised upwards: then you know that the nerves which are to the head of the humerus have been cut or extended or softened: and you know that the union will never fuse in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	 Dislocation that happens towards the chest and breast, or to the back reduction, is made with pressure and extension with hands until it returns, and a remaining pressure and care are administered until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	 If after healing there is heaviness in the member and slowness of its motion, then the sick person should use baths many times until that heaviness is relieved, and it returns to its first nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	 Chapter on the treatment of shoulder dislocation.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter 28.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	 You know that the union of the shoulder dislocates with difficulty and similarly returns with difficulty; and it is indeed dislocated to all parts, but especially in front or behind.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	 And the dislocation of the shoulder is not hidden from you; because it falls under sight and touch, according to whatever form it is dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	 And when you join a dislocated shoulder with the healthy one, that is clearly shown to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	 The joint must be closed, and it cannot be doubled over the arm nor touch its own shoulder.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 You should rush and immediately reduce a dislocation before it gets an abscess.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	 For if an abscess occurs, the reduction becomes difficult; and it may not heal at all, especially when it is towards the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	 Indeed, every kind of dislocation is worse and more painful; and death often accompanies it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	 And its restoration, when it can be reduced, is to extend the hand with two hands; and the arm should be extended, and the hands of the physician are above and below the elbow, and he himself pushes the joint with his thumbs or the root of his palm until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	 Or the dislocation is towards the front: then it is reduced in such a way that the hand doubles over with its own hand until it strikes the elbow which is dislocated with the root of its palm.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	 If the dislocation does not obey reduction, then administer a violent extension, very strong; and it is to be done that two attendants stretch the arm; and they are to hold it so that it is not moved during the extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	 Then the arm is rotated to all parts after it has been wrapped around the hand with a double cloth or wide bandage.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	 And when the physician touches the joint with his hand, he binds it with oil; so that it is one of those things which help in the lubricity of the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	 Then he pushes the joint forcefully until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	 After its reduction, it is necessary to place an ointment on it, which contains styptic and purifying properties with egg white; and it is to be bandaged tightly.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	 And let the arm of the sick person be suspended from the neck for some days.
Deinde soluatur.	 Then it is loosened.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	 If the joint becomes fixed in its place, then loosen the bandage from it and let it be.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	 And if you see that the joint is not well closed, then apply the plaster again, and bandage it and let it be for some days until it is closed.
Deinde solue ipsam.	 Then loosen it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	 If, however, there is pain after the reduction of the joint and it has movement: then administer humectation in a bath, fine friction, and compression until it is lined up, or place upon the joint, that is, the fat of the ram's woolen cloth.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	 Then let it be bound and kept for a day and a night over it.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	 Then remove it, and immerse it in the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	 And when it sweats, then friction the joint with a moderate friction.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	 Then apply to it three times with warm poultices when entering the bath until it is softened.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	 And if you wish, place upon it dried dung, warm, mixed with butter, and bind over it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	 Make this often.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	 It becomes softened, and returns to its former condition.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	 Chapter on the treatment of dislocations by Albucasis.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter XXIX.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	 The hand of Almahassem is frequently dislocated, that is, the joint which is between the arm and the hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	 And the reduction of this dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	 On the contrary, the other joints are more difficult to reduce.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	 However, speed must be taken in the reduction of this dislocation within the hour in which it is dislocated, before the place is loosened: or a hot abscess occurs at the site.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	 Reduction of dislocation is to place Mahassem's weak hand on a table, and let the attendant extend it; and the physician shall place his palm on the prominent joint, and push until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	 Furthermore, it is to be considered if the palm has already retreated into the body of the hand: then let the weak place his back of the hand on a table for extension and reduction; and if the dislocation is proceeding towards the back of the hand, then let the position of the hand be placed intrinsically on the table, that is, the inner part of the hand should be placed on the table, so that the physician may fall upon the prominent joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	 If it returns immediately, that is good; and if not, then bind it with a plaster sitting on the abscess; and leave it alone, do not repeat that.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	 For if it cannot bear (the pressure), nor can you perform reduction of it afterwards when the days pass, but the joint remains according to its twist; and nothing harms the weak unless what is softened for the hand, and nothing can be bound; then know that the nerves have been cut or rubbed.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	 Therefore, there is no skill in it except to bind with a cautery near to its destruction.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	 And perhaps it does not bring anything about.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	 When Almahassem does not return, then place an ointment on him as we have said.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	 Then bind it, and let it be for five days; afterwards it is to be loosened and let go, and exercise the hand.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	 If its movement is taken away, and something heavy happens in it: then soften it with warm water, and rub it gently many times until it is softened.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	 Chapter on the cure of finger dislocations.
Caput XXX.	 Chapter XXX.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	 Chapter XXX: When a finger is dislocated from any part, or from the back of the palm to its body, or the inside of it: then extend the finger and push the dislocation with your thumbs until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	 Then support the head of the digit, and suspend it towards the side where it is dislocated, and leave it for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	 Then extend it until it aligns with its proper position on that day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	 When it is night, tie it according to the story given: and do not cease to loosen it during the day: and exercise it with movement: and tie it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	 Do this for several days until it tightens.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	 And do the same with it if it is dislocated towards the palm of the hand: and tie it to that side, and perform your first operation on it until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	 And do the same with it when it is dislocated towards other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	 Chapter on the treatment of dislocation of the spondylus of the back.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter XXXI.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	 When a person experiences dislocation of the spine, either complete of the neck, or multiple spondyles are displaced from their places: then there is no cure in it, since death approaches the weak.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	 And the sign of this is that the hunger of the weak escapes without will, and he cannot hold it; and many times some members of his are softened, or both legs of him, or both arms of himself, or one of them; or a spondyle is displaced from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	 For many times it is displaced, which is often done to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	 That which is displaced towards the rear is called a humpback.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	 The cure for it is to consider whether the humpback occurs from childhood; then there is no cure in it, and there is no healing at all from it.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	 But in that which occurs from an accident, or blow, or similar things, the ancients have already said the methods of treatment in a lengthy speech.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	 Of this, more often than not it does not return with recovery.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	 I myself have already abbreviated from that which is rarely justified by a large part due to my proximity to the subject: and in my explanation, I explained that, and shaped its instrument in a different way from how they showed it and explained it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	 Therefore, I say that in humpback which occurs from the front part, there is no talent, nor healing from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	 And similarly in that which occurs to both sides.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	 And it is not cured from them, unless that which occurs in the back properly, with what I speak: and it is to extend the weak over his face on an equal plank nearly up to the wall; and expand under him a wet cloth, so as not to harm his chest.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	 Then place a straight stick fixed in the bowl on the ground, at the end of the foot, about its head: and another stick about its feet at the other end of the foot: and let a servant hold the stick, and it shall not be fixed in the bowl.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	 And let another servant hold the other one.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	 Then bend over the head of the patient, and under his chin tie a firm bandage, and extend the end of the bandage to the stick that is at his head, and tie it there.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	 Then bind another bandage above the ankles of the patient, and at the joints of his knees.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	 Then gather all the bandages together, and tie them to the other stick that is at his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	 Then let all the servants extend their bandages to the part of the stick, and neither of the sticks should be moved from its place where it is fixed: but they shall not be fastened, as we have said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	 And the doctor shall put his hands on the hip-bone with force, until he returns: or place a board over it.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	 Then he attaches his feet to the board until he returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	 If he does not return through this treatment, then receive a board whose length is about three arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	 And carve a hole in the wall that we mentioned which is near the patient, into which the end of the board may enter.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	 Then place the middle of the board on the hip-bone.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	 And let the doctor place his feet on the other end.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	 And bind tightly, until the hip-bone is dislocated, and he returns to his place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	 Then, if you wish, operate with a lathe that turns by hand: and it is so that you may carve two sticks in the ground at the head of the patient's last foot, whose length is that of an arm: and at his head at the last foot two sticks.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	 And let the length be that which is between every stick and a palm [width]: and now a hole has been made in every place where a tourniquet runs: and let all the sticks be fixed strongly to the ground so that they do not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	 And insert a round stick: and there is a tourniquet in which a cord is turned in the holes of two sticks.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	 And at the end of it there is a hole where the stick is fixed, whose length is a palm plus what is turned: and similarly in two other sticks.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	 Then bind the cords which you have bound around the chest of the sick man at the tourniquet that is near his head: and bind the cords which you have bound around his legs at the tourniquet that is near his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	 Then stand by every tourniquet the servant who turns his hand with a cloth, with which the tourniquet is turned: and the physician measures the pulse, as we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	 This is the form of the tourniquet that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	 Then when the pulse has been measured and the place is ready, then it is necessary to put on a plaster made from excrement and egg white.
Deinde stuppam.	 Then apply [a substance called] stuppa.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	 Then put on top of the plaster a star-shaped piece from wood, whose width is that of three fingers, or about those [dimensions].
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	 And its length shall be the quantity that covers the depression and the healthy part of the pulse.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	 Then bind it with the cord we have mentioned.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	 And the sick man shall use nourishment that is subtle until he is well.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	 If there remains something raised in the place at the end of healing: then it is necessary to administer medicines that soften and soothe, with the use of the tablet we have mentioned for a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	 And now, it is administered on that plate of lead.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	 Occasionally, a protrusion happens in the last vertebra of the back; it is thought to be a dislocation, and that bone which has become prominent is involved.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	 Therefore, it is not proper to presume this medicine for him; perhaps it will cause death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	 Chapter on the treatment of a dislocated ankle.
Caput XXXII.	 Chapter 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	 Know that the union of the ankle and shoulder joint does not occur except in a dislocation; nor does it happen to them what happens to other joints from a slight displacement and hollowing out.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	 Indeed, the ankle joint is dislocated according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	 Because it is dislocated toward the front and toward the back.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	 It is indeed dislocated most of all to the inside; it is dislocated less frequently to the front and to the back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	 The treatment of a dislocation to the inside is as follows: because when you join the limb of a sick person with a healthy one, it is longer; and the knee joint of the sick person is more prominent than that of a healthy one, and the sick person cannot double his foot near the knee; and there is a place following the knee which is hollowed out by a hollow instrument, because the head of the hip has already reached that place.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	 The sign of one who has a dislocation to the outside is that his symptoms are opposite these symptoms.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	 The sign of one who has a dislocation to the front is that he spreads out the healthy leg to its full extent; however, he cannot double it without pain in the knee, and if he attempts to walk, he cannot step forward on it; and urine retention occurs in him, his knee becomes hollowed out, and during walking there is a striking of his foot on the heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	 The sign of the one who experiences dislocation at the posterior [region] is that it does not extend the knee, nor can he double it before doubling the thigh; and his leg is also shortened on the other side; and the thigh is softened, and it has the head of the hip in that place.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	 The reduction [of this dislocation] is of the following forms: consider then, if the dislocation is old and has already degenerated with it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	 Then if you administer the reduction of it, and it remains according to its position; then there is no treatment at all in it.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	 Therefore, one should not make a rash assumption about it [the condition].
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	 In the one whose dislocation is recent, and belongs to one of the four forms of dislocations: then go ahead and apply pressure on it, extend it towards the inside and outside, and move it right and left; perhaps it will return, and no other care is needed.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	 If it does not return in this way, then a strong attendant should prepare and extend the leg from below: either with his hands or with a rope that ties above the knee; and another assistant should extend his hand above, so that he may insert his hands under the armpits of the patient.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	 Then tie a soft rope around the root of the hip and hold the end of another rope.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	 And the extension [of the leg] should be from the front of the thigh to the neck of the collarbone, or from the back to the backbone.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	 And the extension [of all] should be one and the same until the sick man with his body is raised from the ground and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	 This is indeed a common form of the four forms [of dislocation].
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	 If the dislocation returns as we said, it is good; and if not, then it is necessary to follow the specific cure mentioned below.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 In the reduction [of a dislocation], when it is toward the inner parts, the sick one must lie on his healthy side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	 Then put the bandage over the root of the hip, where it is between the head of the hip and the place that is below the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	 Then extend the bandage upward from the groin to the higher part of the body, to the neck (region).
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	 Then another strong man takes hold of his arm and reduces the large place of the weak hip by extending it to the outside with great force.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	 Now it is back in its own place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	 And this method is easier than the other methods of treatment, by which this limb is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	 If, however, it is dislocated above you and does not obey you at all with this method of treatment, then it is necessary that two weak feet be bound together with a strong bandage, loosely, on both heels, and on both knees: and the length of each one should be four fingers' breadths: and the weak leg should be extended by more than two fingers.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	 Then the sick one is suspended over the top of a log that is in the house; and its length from the ground should be two forearms' lengths.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	 Then command a strong youth to bind the head of the hip; and suspend another with the sick one: and another youth pushes, while binding the hip with force, because when it is bound together, it returns quickly to its own place.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	 In the reduction [of a dislocation], when it is toward the outer parts, the sick one must lie on a couch, as we have said in the one with a hump.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	 And bind the bandage over his weak leg and over his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	 Then two logs are placed, one at his feet and another at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	 Then place a support stick in the middle of the foot, secure it well; upon which let the wet cloths be wrapped, so as not to hurt the weak; and let the stick be between his thighs, so that he is not drawn downwards during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	 Then let every attendant go to their place, and the doctor shall adjust the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	 If it obeys in returning, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	 And if not, place it on the table and press it evenly, as we have said in swelling, likewise.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 However, it is necessary that the weak one lies on the side of the healthy.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	 And when the dislocation is towards the front, then it should be extended quickly; and this is according to the same narrative on the foot; and the doctor shall place the palm of his right hand on the sick person's thigh.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	 Then bend him with one hand, and with that bending place him extended towards the lower part of the leg.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	 If the dislocation is towards the back: then it should not be extended downwards; and the sick one should not be raised up from the ground; instead, he should be placed on a hard surface, as it should also be done if his dislocation is towards the outside, according to what we said about his lying on two sides: and it is on his face and his limbs are extended; according to what we said recently.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	 And it is necessary that compression is administered with a board also on the place from which the joint departs, when the reduction is completed according to what is required.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	 And the sign of his reduction is not hidden from you; and it is to extend two legs of the sick one; and when you see them even, and the sick person tightens his leg, and expands himself without any resistance; then you will know that the limb has returned, according to what is required: then join the thighs, and apply a plaster, and tie with gauze, that is, roller; in such a way that the dislocation does not move towards any part; and let the sick one remain quiet for three or four days.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	 Then unfasten the ligament, and apply the plaster, and compare the leg with the other: then if you see that they are equal in position, then you will know that the dislocation is already fixed: therefore leave the patient to walk.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	 And if you see something softening: then return, and apply the plaster again, and bind it according to your first binding: and let it be for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	 Then unfasten it and cause it to slow down in walking on both sides, until it recovers well.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	 Chapter on the Dislocations of the Knee.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter XXXIII.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	 The knee is dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	 It is dislocated to the outside, to the inside, and to the below (i.e., the back).
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	 And it is not dislocated to the front.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	 The sign of this dislocation is that you order the patient to apply his leg to his hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	 But if it does not stick to the hip: then know, that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	 And the restoration of all the modes of dislocation is that you make the patient sit upright, so that he now extends his leg if possible over it and presses his back against his face; and place his foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	 Then cause the knee to stick to your palms, and keep them straight across the knee.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	 Then apply two palms of your hand firmly on both sides of the knee.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	 And let another servant extend his foot, until the knee returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	 The sign of return is that the leg sticks to the hip gently, not forcefully.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	 Then apply a plaster to it, and cause the leg to stick to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	 Then bind them together with ointment for three or four days.
Deinde solue ea.	 Then dissolve it.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	 And let not the sick person walk for some days until he is cured.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	 If he refuses to return, then give him a strong extension with ligaments, whose description is found in the treatment of an aneurysm, until he returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	 Chapter on the treatment of dislocated heel bone.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter XXXIV.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	 Calcaneus is sometimes removed by a slight removal, and sometimes it is dislocated according to its extent.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	 Dislocation of it happens either towards the internal or external parts.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	 The sign of its dislocation is that you see the calcaneus swollen, projecting towards the part to which it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	 But the treatment of its removal is easy return: and it is that it is extended with ease with hands, and adjusted until it returns.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	 However, in its treatment when it is dislocated according to its extent, one must make the patient sit straight: and a strong assistant should hold him very firmly from the back part of his middle.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	 Then hold with your right hand the foot from above its part, and with your left hand from below the foot at the place of the ankle.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	 Then pull the foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	 And with your left hand in two places.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	 Then extend it with your left and push the sole of the foot towards you with your right without strain.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	 Do that twice as we have said.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	 Then push the sole of the foot towards the leg at the third place, and you pull the ankle.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	 If therefore it returns at one or two places according to this method and you see the foot aligned, it is good: and if not, then repeat the procedure on him; because he will return.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	 But if the reduction of it with him as we have said is forbidden to you: then make the patient lie on his back on the ground, and fix a peg in the ground firmly so that he falls between his thighs; and now roll a cloth over him so that he does not harm the sick one.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	 Then receive an assistant his thigh: then another extends the leg, either with hands or with a strap that binds around its neck.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	 Then let every attendant extend himself opposite to the extension of his own [position]: and let the pillow be standing between the two hips of the sick person, holding him, so that his body is not drawn downwards during the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	 Then the physician should dislocate [the bone] with his hands, and another attendant holds the sound leg towards the lower parts.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	 For dislocation is regained quickly.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	 When therefore dislocation has returned and the health of its return is shown to you: then put an ointment and a plaster, and sew it firmly with bandages, and bind the foot with a bandage to the leg.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	 And it is necessary that you be careful or fearful of the nerves which are above the heel at the back, so that the bandage is not too tight and harms them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	 Then let him go for two or three days.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	 If the bandage becomes softened, sew it again: then dissolve it on the third or fourth day: and forbid the sick person from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	 But if he attempts to walk before that time, there will not be safety unless the dislocation is dissolved upon him, and it is spoiled, and it will not receive treatment afterwards.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	 If it happens to him a hot abscess: then it is necessary that you administer for its sedation what was previously told in another place about the cure, and an embrocation until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	 Chapter on Dislocation of Fingers of the Foot and Cure.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter XXXV.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	 It is necessary that it be equalized what is being dislocated with little extension without effort: and this is not difficult, rather it is easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	 But if the dislocation is in some nodes of the back of the foot: then it is necessary that the sick person sits his foot on an equal place to the ground, or on a table: and he stands thus as walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	 Then you stand, and place your foot upon that which projects from those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	 Then press it with your foot with force until it returns and you see it has become even, and no projection appears in its place.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	 Then place under the heel of that foot a board which can hold the entire foot, having two handles.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	 Then bind it with a ligature decent three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	 Then unbind it and let him rest from walking for many days until it binds and assures against relapse.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	 On the types of dislocations with wound or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter XXXVI.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	 When something happens to it (the wound or fracture) and you attempt its cure and restoration, often death occurs; and therefore, one should not presume about the cure of such a thing unless he is wise in long practice, merciful, pious, slow, not bold, nor presumptuous; and that he uses for the beginning of treatment only medicines which quiet inflammations hot only; and that he allows the weak to the divine judgment.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	 Unless you see or hope for recovery from destruction with mildness of illness and where something appears with hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	 Therefore, attempt the reduction of it immediately at the beginning of the matter, before a hot abscess occurs.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	 If the limb then returns as we desire, then administer a regimen that quiets the abscess; and cure the wound with it which suits it from dry ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	 If the dislocation is with a fracture, and pus-filled sores separate from the bone occur, then attempt their removal; and make in it what was said for simple illnesses in the places of those sores.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	 And take care according to your strength, and guard yourself from the entrance into the way of fear; according to what was previously said to you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	 It is better for you with your Creator, and more lasting for your glory, and more healthy for your body with them at your time.
